climbs.name: Pacemaker
climbs.fa: John Black, Reinhard Fabische, & Chris Rowe, August 1998    FFA: Chris Geisler & Tony Richardson, 2009

content.description:
Something of a local myth and legend. 

A massive 1700m/5600ft Grade VI alpine big wall located on the North Face of Robie Reid.

The first ascent, established over eight days, was nearly 40 pitches going at 5.10a A1.

In 2007, rock fall destroyed several of the original pitches and created a large new roof. The damaged area is approximately 50'x60'x30'. Many of the original belay bolts were destroyed during this rock fall.

In 2009, Chris Geisler & Tony Richardson completed the second, and first all free ascent, simul-climbing 28 long, runout pitches, with a bivy 2/3 of the way up at Ice Block Ledge.



North Face of Robie Reid, located at the head of Glacier Creek.

The standard route. A long slog of a hike leads to some enjoyable scrambling with great views.

From the infamous double gates:

Pass the gates and continue down the road, loosing approx 250m of elevation. At roughly the 7th(?) switchback, there is a faint trail going off into the bushes on the right. There are a few pieces of faded flagging tape marking the start of the trail. It is easy to miss.

Trailhead Location: 49.37766, -122.32405

Once off the road, the trail continues to descend slowly to lake level. Continue along for about 2km to the end of the lake. The trail then turns left and starts to gain elevation slowly through the forest. Around the 3km mark is when the steepness increases. The next 2km are very steep and slightly overgrown, but throughout, the trail is very well marked with orange flagging tape. 

Roughly 5km from the start of the trail, you finally break through the tree-line to the boggy and buggy "tarns", commonly used as a bivy location if doing the route over two days. 

From here, continue NW along the ridge to the base of the slabs. Follow the slabs up and left to reach the permanent snowfield. Cross the snowfield further NW to more slabs. Scramble across the slabs until you reach the first crux gully located ROUGHLY here: 49.42536, -122.34558

Climb the 4th/low-5th class gully up past the rappel chockstone. Continue up the loose gully to another 4th class crux. 

Once at the end of the gully, continue across more slabs, then traverse around the false summit to the West on a moderately-exposed ledge. 

This should place you at the start of the enjoyable 1km-long ridge to the summit. 



From Dewdney Trunk Road, turn onto the Florence Lake FSR and follow it for approx 20km. Follow the FSR straight, for the first 10km or so. Eventually you reach a Y-junction with a sign for Rocky Point going to the right. Turn left here. 

Continue down the FSR and make a left at an unmarked side road located here:

49.36949, -122.32483

This is an easy turn to miss. Continue down the small road for about a kilometre until you reach the infamous "double gates". Park in the small pullout on the left.

Parking area located here:

49.37122, -122.32585


Cross Allouete Lake to the far North side of the lake. 

There is a small rocky beach that a canoe or kayak could be landed and tied off to tree located here: 49.38945, -122.31852

The approach trail passes by the beach a few metres to the North.

Helmet, 30m rope (if rapping cruxes), ice axe and crampons (depending on conditions)
Robie Reid is a prominent peak located in Golden Ears Provincial Park, well visible on the mountain skyline from Abbotsford, Coquitlam, Surrey and Maple Ridge.
